segments.text: We've all heard of Google's

yesterday, Google had shipped a major
update to it. With the release of agent
skills, skills are an open standard that
extend what your agent can do. Whether
it's project specific workflows or
global utilities, you can now package
knowledge and behavior into reusable
skills that your agent can automatically
discover and apply. And this is truly a
big update. with agent skills.
Anti-gravity significantly upgrades the
build test prove loop. This takes the
flight tracker demo as an example where
instead of just redescribing same steps
into every prompt like API integration,
real-time browser testing as well as bug
fixing loops or even something like
video report generation. These workflows
are now packaged as reusable skills
using simple markdown or YAM files. The
agent can automatically select the right
skills at the right time, leading to
faster builds, more consistent results,
higher quality automated testing, and
even smoother browser interaction. You
also get verifiable proof artifacts
every single run thanks to this. Now,
skills are reusable, and you can
essentially pack it as an instruction
that teaches anti-gravity, the agent, to

needed. All you got to do is simply go
ahead and add a skill to your workspace.
And you can do that by creating a skills
MD file. Just as an example, I created a
skills MD file with the agent itself. I
actually instructed the anti-gravity
agent to create the skills for me. This
is where it can discover all available
skills. Whenever I am prompting the
agent to develop anything, it will

the descriptions that are listed within
this MD file. and it can execute the
instructions, scripts and best
practices. So for example, we have a
couple of skills that have been created
to run the crypto exchange itself. This
will start, stop and manage the back and
front-end servers automatically. Whereas
before it would take multiple processes
starting this overall project up. You
can also see that there is a skill to
add trading pairs to the crypto
exchange. So, if I want, I can simply
add in a new pair whenever it has been
recently added to my exchange right
away. So, let's test this out. I'm going
to start up the exchange and send in
this prompt. It'll use my agent skill
and easily start up. And just like that,
it was able to start up within my local
host, which I can access from my web
browser. And you can see that it was
able to easily start this up, whereas
before it would take a couple of
processes to set this all up and start
up my exchange. Next, I'm going to use

adding it. And thanks to the new skill,
it was able to add the new arbitrum
pair. And you can see that it did this

anti-gravity thanks to this skill. And
with that context aware engineering
already set, it was able to easily make
this process super fast. But in essence,
this is turning anti-gravity into a
self-guided contextawware engineer

thanks to these skills. The next update
is a big one, but not great for power
